values.description:
**Test Condition**

1. drcsim_2.5 branch
2. any of the qual worlds
     
**Steps**
1. Start a qual world

2. Do some stuff, keyboard teleop for example

3. Run `tail -n 1 -f /tmp/qual_task_{n}/state.log`

4. Note the current simulation time, and then run `gzlog stop`

**Testing**

You should see the following line appear in the `state.log` file:
    </gazebo_log>

Atlas should not fall over.

And no more data should be written to `state.log`

Playback of the log file should advance up to the time at which you entered `gzlog stop`.
values.title: Fix gzlog stop command line

values.description:
This pull request adds zlib compression as an alternative to bzip2 (both are available via boost). Some testing has shown zlib to have faster compression, though with potentially larger file sizes. Large amounts of memory have been observed to accumulate in buffers while logging with drcsim (see issue #682), so this may mitigate that issue.

The default is still bzip2; to test with zlib compression, use the following command-line argument when invoking gazebo: `--record_encoding=zlib`.

UPDATE:

* Added @iche033 's changes to LogRecord_TEST and fix to race condition. I had to add a delay in the test since LogRecord::Start may return before the RunWrite, RunUpdate, and Cleanup threads have started, and quickly calling LogRecord::Stop could make things hang.
values.title: Logging speed improvement: add zlib option for compression (fix #682)

summary.raw:
This pull request adds zlib compression as an alternative to bzip2 (both are available via boost). Some testing has shown zlib to have faster compression, though with potentially larger file sizes. Large amounts of memory have been observed to accumulate in buffers while logging with drcsim (see issue #682), so this may mitigate that issue.

The default is still bzip2; to test with zlib compression, use the following command-line argument when invoking gazebo: `--record_encoding=zlib`.

UPDATE:

* Added @iche033 's changes to LogRecord_TEST and fix to race condition. I had to add a delay in the test since LogRecord::Start may return before the RunWrite, RunUpdate, and Cleanup threads have started, and quickly calling LogRecord::Stop could make things hang.
summary.html:
This pull request adds zlib compression as an alternative to bzip2 (both are available via boost). Some testing has shown zlib to have faster compression, though with potentially larger file sizes. Large amounts of memory have been observed to accumulate in buffers while logging with drcsim (see issue #682), so this may mitigate that issue.

The default is still bzip2; to test with zlib compression, use the following command-line argument when invoking gazebo: --record_encoding=zlib.

UPDATE:

  • Added @iche033 's changes to LogRecord_TEST and fix to race condition. I had to add a delay in the test since LogRecord::Start may return before the RunWrite, RunUpdate, and Cleanup threads have started, and quickly calling LogRecord::Stop could make things hang.

values.description:
I've been testing with OSX because sometimes bugs are easier to find with BSD's strictness.

In this case, I was observing hangs while waiting for master, and I tracked it down to an incorrect length for the header in Connection::Read. Since ParseHeader takes a std::string argument, there was an implicit conversion from a char[] array to std::string, but the length was not correct on osx. I frequently observed headers being returned with 22 bytes, when only 8 bytes were expected. This makes an explicit conversion to std::string with the correct length of the header.
values.title: OSX bug: char array converted to string with incorrect length

summary.raw:
I've been testing with OSX because sometimes bugs are easier to find with BSD's strictness.

In this case, I was observing hangs while waiting for master, and I tracked it down to an incorrect length for the header in Connection::Read. Since ParseHeader takes a std::string argument, there was an implicit conversion from a char[] array to std::string, but the length was not correct on osx. I frequently observed headers being returned with 22 bytes, when only 8 bytes were expected. This makes an explicit conversion to std::string with the correct length of the header.
summary.html:
I've been testing with OSX because sometimes bugs are easier to find with BSD's strictness.

In this case, I was observing hangs while waiting for master, and I tracked it down to an incorrect length for the header in Connection::Read. Since ParseHeader takes a std::string argument, there was an implicit conversion from a char[] array to std::string, but the length was not correct on osx. I frequently observed headers being returned with 22 bytes, when only 8 bytes were expected. This makes an explicit conversion to std::string with the correct length of the header.

values.description:
Fix for drift issue #680.   With this patch, [drcsim pull request #309](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/309/remove-auto-disable-for-atlas/diff).

Update to improve physics solution by

1.  Warm starting bi-lateral constraints.
1.  Reordering so bilateral contacts are solved first, followed by contact normal forces, and lastly frictional forces at contacts.
1.  Further decrease successive over-relaxation for frictional directions to 0.25x those of normal directions.

First one improves overall physics solution by starting with `labmda` from previous simulation step, 2) and 3) removes the rotational drift and reduces linear drift significantly.
values.title: improve physics solution (issue #680)

summary.raw:
Fix for drift issue #680.   With this patch, [drcsim pull request #309](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/309/remove-auto-disable-for-atlas/diff).

Update to improve physics solution by

1.  Warm starting bi-lateral constraints.
1.  Reordering so bilateral contacts are solved first, followed by contact normal forces, and lastly frictional forces at contacts.
1.  Further decrease successive over-relaxation for frictional directions to 0.25x those of normal directions.

First one improves overall physics solution by starting with `labmda` from previous simulation step, 2) and 3) removes the rotational drift and reduces linear drift significantly.
summary.html:
Fix for drift issue #680. With this patch, drcsim pull request #309.

Update to improve physics solution by

  1. Warm starting bi-lateral constraints.
  2. Reordering so bilateral contacts are solved first, followed by contact normal forces, and lastly frictional forces at contacts.
  3. Further decrease successive over-relaxation for frictional directions to 0.25x those of normal directions.

First one improves overall physics solution by starting with labmda from previous simulation step, 2) and 3) removes the rotational drift and reduces linear drift significantly.

values.description:
We decided to disable clouds only on the server side as opposed to previous approach that focused on offscreen rendering. Disabled calls to clouds/moon updates in skyx for performance reasons. 

Comparison of avg time for a Render() call sampled over 300 frames on a multisense camera:

before: 0.0114833  sec

after: 0.00927631 sec

Caveat here is that you'll still see clouds in gzclient's camera visualization.

Update:

- Set visibility of clouds and moon to false when disabled (Previously it only stops updates when disabled)

Update2:

- change target to gazebo_1.8
values.title: Disable skyx clouds/moon update on server side for performance

values.description:
Slight change to sensor update strategy

Delays happen when multiple sensors compete to hit their update rates, as the result the one that takes the longest to update may throttle others with similar update cycles. Factoring in the delays allows the sensor to catch-up when needed to hit its target update rate.

This happened to the multisense camera and gpu ray sensor. Now, they should publish at the specified frequency (30hz for multisense camera, and 40hz for gpu ray sensor). 

Fix for issue #688, and drcsim issue [#251](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/251/laser-running-slow)
values.title: Factor in sensor update delays in each update

summary.raw:
Slight change to sensor update strategy

Delays happen when multiple sensors compete to hit their update rates, as the result the one that takes the longest to update may throttle others with similar update cycles. Factoring in the delays allows the sensor to catch-up when needed to hit its target update rate.

This happened to the multisense camera and gpu ray sensor. Now, they should publish at the specified frequency (30hz for multisense camera, and 40hz for gpu ray sensor). 

Fix for issue #688, and drcsim issue [#251](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/251/laser-running-slow)
summary.html:
Slight change to sensor update strategy

Delays happen when multiple sensors compete to hit their update rates, as the result the one that takes the longest to update may throttle others with similar update cycles. Factoring in the delays allows the sensor to catch-up when needed to hit its target update rate.

This happened to the multisense camera and gpu ray sensor. Now, they should publish at the specified frequency (30hz for multisense camera, and 40hz for gpu ray sensor).

Fix for issue #688, and drcsim issue #251

values.description: Profiling identified the functions ODEPhysics::GetMaxContacts and Collision::GetMaxContacts called in [ODEPhysics::Collide](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/df297492575df38dbe47871c30a0382915171aa3/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEPhysics.cc?at=gazebo_1.8#cl-797) as taking up 0.5% of computation time. These functions are slow because they retrieve data stored in the sdf data structure, and ODEPhysics::Collide is called multiple times per physics update. This pull request stores the maxContacts parameter as a private member variable to make GetMaxContacts faster.
values.title: Performance improvement: GetMaxContacts

summary.raw: Profiling identified the functions ODEPhysics::GetMaxContacts and Collision::GetMaxContacts called in [ODEPhysics::Collide](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/df297492575df38dbe47871c30a0382915171aa3/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEPhysics.cc?at=gazebo_1.8#cl-797) as taking up 0.5% of computation time. These functions are slow because they retrieve data stored in the sdf data structure, and ODEPhysics::Collide is called multiple times per physics update. This pull request stores the maxContacts parameter as a private member variable to make GetMaxContacts faster.
summary.html: Profiling identified the functions ODEPhysics::GetMaxContacts and Collision::GetMaxContacts called in ODEPhysics::Collide as taking up 0.5% of computation time. These functions are slow because they retrieve data stored in the sdf data structure, and ODEPhysics::Collide is called multiple times per physics update. This pull request stores the maxContacts parameter as a private member variable to make GetMaxContacts faster.

values.description:
Remove string comparisons

Clear message when publishing

Update: Use tmp vector (collisionNames) to store collision names and delay the conversion to pointers later in NewContact() to ensure this is done after all entities have been loaded.

Update2: do conversion in `CreateFilter()` first. `NewContact()` then tries to find remaining ones on every iteration, it's costly but should not affect VRC, we should optimize later.
values.title: Contact manager custom publisher performance improvement

summary.raw:
Remove string comparisons

Clear message when publishing

Update: Use tmp vector (collisionNames) to store collision names and delay the conversion to pointers later in NewContact() to ensure this is done after all entities have been loaded.

Update2: do conversion in `CreateFilter()` first. `NewContact()` then tries to find remaining ones on every iteration, it's costly but should not affect VRC, we should optimize later.
summary.html:
Remove string comparisons

Clear message when publishing

Update: Use tmp vector (collisionNames) to store collision names and delay the conversion to pointers later in NewContact() to ensure this is done after all entities have been loaded.

Update2: do conversion in CreateFilter() first. NewContact() then tries to find remaining ones on every iteration, it's costly but should not affect VRC, we should optimize later.

values.description:
* add residual smoothing with smoothing coefficient of 0.01 for contact constraints.
* additional 10 iteration cycles to improve friction forces.
* (minor) moved some warm start code around.

with this patch, Atlas should virtually not slip in stand mode, and the hand can grasp a cylinder and hold it indefinitely.
values.title: deal with noisy friction solution

summary.raw:
* add residual smoothing with smoothing coefficient of 0.01 for contact constraints.
* additional 10 iteration cycles to improve friction forces.
* (minor) moved some warm start code around.

with this patch, Atlas should virtually not slip in stand mode, and the hand can grasp a cylinder and hold it indefinitely.
summary.html:
• add residual smoothing with smoothing coefficient of 0.01 for contact constraints.
  • additional 10 iteration cycles to improve friction forces.
  • (minor) moved some warm start code around.

with this patch, Atlas should virtually not slip in stand mode, and the hand can grasp a cylinder and hold it indefinitely.

values.description: Part 1 of  pull request #544
